EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Southern Cayuga Lake Intermunicipal Water Commission (SCLIWC) Bolton Point Water System operates and maintains a water treatment plant located on East Shore Drive, in the Village of Lansing, New York.  The facility treats approximately 2.4 million gallons of water from Cayuga Lake per day and distributes it to five municipalities ? Towns of Dryden, Ithaca and Lansing, and Villages of Cayuga Heights and Lansing.  Bolton Point uses gaseous chlorine to disinfect the water before it is distributed to the general population.  The facility receives chlorine in one ton (2,000 pound) cylinders and stores up to a maximum of four cylinders at any given time.

Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency?s Risk Management Program Rule (40 CFR part 68).  The Bolton Point facility has prepared a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.

Accident Prevention
The Bolton Point facility has used chlorine in its disinfection system since becoming operational in 1976.  In that time facility personnel have taken considerable care in the storage and handling of chlorine, and there have been no releases of chlorine.  The facility receives one-ton cylinders by truck, lifts them using a motorized crane designed specifically for moving one ton cylinders, and places them in saddles in a locked building.  Before accepting any chlorine cylinder, facility operators inspect it for leaks.  If a chlorine supplier delivers a cylinder that appears to be in less than good condition or the person who delivers the cylinder does not follow proper safety procedures, that supplier will be removed from the vendor list until that supplier verifies that they have corrected the deficiency.  The storage facility is used solely for chlorine storage and connection to the disinfection system and, therefore, is not subject to daily traffic.  In fact the chlorine storage area is only accessed when a cylind

er is empty (approximately every 4 to 6 weeks).  Facility personnel do, however, check the storage area through a window inside the plant several times during each shift.  Continuous monitoring of the storage area is performed by means of a closed circuit TV camera.  Another camera monitors the approaches to the chlorine storage area.

The design of the chlorine feed system is very simple and inherently safe.  The system is operated under a constant vacuum as opposed to utilizing pressure from the chlorine cylinders.  The vacuum is generated at the point at which the chlorine is mixed with the water.  Without a constant vacuum, the valve on the cylinder-mounted chlorinator will close.  This prevents chlorine from entering the system when the system is not in use.  In the unlikely event of a break in the chlorine feed line, the system would lose vacuum, and the inlet valve would close automatically, stopping flow from the chlorine cylinder at the feed system.

Chlorine sensors, which alarm when the chlorine concentration exceeds 1 part per million (ppm), are located within the chlorine storage room and chlorinator room ).  The alarm notifies the operators of low concentrations (greater than or equal to 1ppm) of chlorine in these two areas so they can respond immediately and correct the situation.  The alarms are tested monthly.

Five Year Accident History

Through training, prevention measures, and safe operating practices, the facility has not experienced a release of chlorine that has effected offsite receptors during its entire 28 year operating history.  

Emergency Response

The facility operators are trained to respond to a minor release of chlorine within the chlorine storage area.  The operators wearing the proper personal protective equipment are capable of entering the storage area and repairing or replacing faulty equipment.  In the event of  a more significant release, the facility has a mutual aid agreement with the local emergency planning committee(LEP

C), that would coordinate the response of HAZMAT- trained personnel from the Lansing Fire Department, Ithaca Fire Department and Cornell University?s Department of Environmental Health, if needed, to assist in mitigating the release.

Changes to Improve Safety

The Bolton point facility identified and implemented minor changes to the existing operating procedures that have improved safety.  In the interval between the creation of a risk management program in 1999 and the update in 2004 the facility has implemented the following changes to increase safety and reliability of the chlorine disinfection system.
?    Installed a closed circuit TV camera system to monitor the chlorine storage area and its approaches
?    Installed new chlorine valves
?    Installed new chlorine analyzers for more precise control of the chlorine feed system
?    A new computer based monitoring and control system is being developed and should be operational by December 2004.  
?    Local law enforcement personnel have been acquainted with the facility and the chlorine system as part of a continuing upgrading of security.
